trans-unit.source: Hosts and formats flow content with advanced document features, such as pagination and columns.
<xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> enforces a strong content model for child content.
Top-level child elements contained in a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> must be derived from <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Block>.
Valid top-level child elements include the following:

The default <xref:System.Windows.DataTemplate> for <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> contains a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.FlowDocumentReader> that is used to display the document if you use <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> as the root element in a XAML file.

If <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> is not the root element, the document can be displayed in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.FlowDocumentScrollViewer>, a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.FlowDocumentPageViewer>, or a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.FlowDocumentReader> control.
You can also edit a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.RichTextBox> control.
Initializes a new, empty instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref> class.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref> class, adding a specified <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Block"></xref> element as the initial content.

Valid input types for `block` include <xref:System.Windows.Documents.BlockUIContainer>, <xref:System.Windows.Documents.List>, <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Paragraph>, <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Section>, and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Table>.
An object deriving from the abstract <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Block"></xref> class, to be added as the initial content.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Brush"></xref> used to fill the background of content area.
For a table of swatches that show the available predefined brush colors, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.Brushes>.
The brush used to fill the background of the content area, or `null` to not use a background brush.
Gets the top-level <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Block"></xref> elements of the contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.BlockCollection> returned by this property to enumerate or manipulate contents of a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>.
Top-level child elements contained in a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> must be derived from <xref:System.Windows.Documents.Block>.
Valid top-level child elements include the following:

A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.BlockCollection"></xref> containing the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Block"></xref> elements that make up the contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets or sets the column gap value, which indicates the spacing between columns in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Getting this property returns the current column gap.
Setting this value changes the currently effective column gap, and may cause content to reflow.
The column gap cannot exceed the current <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> minus any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PagePadding%2A>.
If the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnGap%2A> property exceeds this limit, the effective column gap is reduced to observe this limit.
This property has no effect if <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnWidth%2A> is `null`.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above (excepting `Auto`), followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
Causes the effective spacing between columns to be set to the current value of the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.LineHeight%2A> property.
Equivalent to a property value of <xref:System.Double.NaN>.
The column gap, in device independent pixels.
A value of (equivalent to an attribute value of "Auto") indicates that the column gap is equal to the property.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Brush"></xref> used to draw the rule between columns.
The column rule is a line that is drawn between columns, and is used to visually separate columns of content.
For a table of swatches that show the available predefined brush colors, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.Brushes>.
This property has no effect if the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnRuleWidth%2A> property is 0 or `null`.
Column rules are displayed only when there are two or more columns.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Brush"></xref> to use when drawing the rule line between columns, or `null` to not use a background brush.
Gets or sets the column rule width.
The column rule is a line that is drawn between columns, and is used to visually separate columns of content.
This property has no effect if the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnRuleBrush%2A> property is `null`.
Column rules are only displayed when there are two or more columns.
The column rule width is constrained to be less than or equal to the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnGap%2A>.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The column rule width, in device independent pixels.
Gets or sets the minimum desired width of the columns in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> dynamically adjusts its contents to maximize content presentation within the available display space.
The number of visible columns is determined by the number of columns that can fit in available display space, given the minimum column width specified by this property.
The actual column width may be greater than the value specified by this property.
Changing the size of the window in either direction will result in columns being dynamically regenerated to make the best use of space.
In this way, the content dynamically adapts to the user's environment.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, (excepting `Auto`) followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
Causes column width to be automatically calculated to be 20 times the current <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontSize%2A>.
The minimum desired column width, in device independent pixels.
A value of <xref href="System.Double.NaN"></xref> causes only one column to be displayed, regardless of the page width.
Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer"></xref> that represents the end of the content in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ContentEnd%2A> property is often used to append content to the end of a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer> returned by this property always has its <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer.LogicalDirection%2A> set to <xref:System.Windows.Documents.LogicalDirection?displayProperty=fullName>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer"></xref> representing the end of the contents in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer"></xref> that represents the start of content within a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ContentStart%2A> property is often used to insert content to the beginning of a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer> returned by this property always has its <xref:System.Windows.Documents.TextPointer.LogicalDirection%2A> set to <xref:System.Windows.Documents.LogicalDirection?displayProperty=fullName>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.TextPointerContext"></xref> representing the start of the contents in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets or sets the relative direction for flow of content in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Getting this property returns the currently effective flow direction.
Setting this property causes the contents of the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> to reflow in the indicated direction.
The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FlowDirection%2A> of content typically corresponds to the innate flow direction of the language being represented.
Hebrew and Arabic are examples of languages that naturally flow from right to left.
English, German, and Russian are examples of languages that naturally flow from left to right.
The value of this property is not automatically changed to match the language used by the operating system.
If you need to use a different value then the default of <xref:System.Windows.FlowDirection.LeftToRight>, you must specify it yourself.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.FlowDirection"></xref> values that specifies the relative flow direction.
Gets or sets the preferred top-level font family for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontFamily%2A> settings on child elements will override this top-level setting.
When multiple families are specified, the second and subsequent font families serve as fallback families to be used in cases where the primary font family is unavailable or not applicable.
This property specifies a preference only.

If the specified font family is not available, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> will silently fall back to the font determined by the <xref:System.Windows.SystemFonts.MessageFontFamily%2A?displayProperty=fullName> value.
A string specifying a font family name.
A string specifying multiple font family names, each separated by a comma (any whitespace following a comma is ignored).

The first font family specified serves as the primary font family; subsequent font families serve as fallback families to be used in cases where the primary font family is unavailable or not applicable.
For example, `"Arial, Century Gothic"` specifies Arial as the primary font family, with Century Gothic as the fallback font family.
A string specifying a folder containing the font, along with a font family name.
The folder and font family name are delimited by a # character.
The folder reference may be absolute, or relative.
A string specifying a [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_uri](~/includes/tlasharptla-uri-md.md)] for the font, along with a font family name.
The [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri](~/includes/tla2sharptla-uri-md.md)] and font family name are delimited by a # character.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.FontFamily"></xref> object specifying the preferred font family, or a primary preferred font family with one or more fallback font families.
The default is the font determined by the <xref href="System.Windows.SystemFonts.MessageFontFamily"></xref> value.
Gets or sets the top-level font size for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontSize%2A> settings on child elements override this top-level setting.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The desired font size to use, in device independent pixels).
The default is determined by the <xref href="System.Windows.SystemFonts.MessageFontSize"></xref> value.
Gets or sets the top-level font-stretching characteristics for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontStretch%2A> settings on child elements override this top-level setting.
A member of the <xref href="System.Windows.FontStretch"></xref> class that specifies the desired font-stretching characteristics to use.
Gets or sets the top-level font style for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontStyle%2A> settings on child elements override this top-level setting.
A member of the <xref href="System.Windows.FontStyles"></xref> class that specifies the desired font style.
The default is determined by the <xref href="System.Windows.SystemFonts.MessageFontStyle"></xref> value.
Gets or sets the top-level font weight for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontWeight%2A> settings on child elements override this top-level setting.
A member of the <xref href="System.Windows.FontWeights"></xref> class that specifies the desired font weight.
The default is determined by the <xref href="System.Windows.SystemFonts.MessageFontWeight"></xref> value.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Brush"></xref> to apply to the text contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
For a table of swatches that shows the available predefined brush colors, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.Brushes>.
Any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.Foreground%2A> settings on child elements override this top-level setting.
The brush used to apply to the text contents.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnWidth"></xref> value is flexible or fixed.

The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.IsColumnWidthFlexible%2A> property determines the manner in which any excess content area width (that is, the difference between the page width and the width of the content after it is laid out) is distributed among columns.

A setting of `true` means that the extra space is distributed equally to each column; in this case, columns may be sized wider than the width specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnWidth%2A> property.

A setting of `false` means excess space is distributed to the padding on the right side of the page; in this case, columns will always size to the width specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.ColumnWidth%2A> property (so long as that width is smaller than the width of the page minus any <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PagePadding%2A>).
The following figure illustrates the difference in layout when this property is `true` or `false`.
Light blue represents columns of content in a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>.
`true` if the column width is flexible; `false` if the column width is fixed.
Gets the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.ContentElement.IsEnabled"></xref> property for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The value of the <xref href="System.Windows.ContentElement.IsEnabled"></xref> property for the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether automatic hyphenation of words is enabled or disabled.
The automatic word hyphenation feature enables a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> to automatically break and hyphenate words, based on current layout conditions.
This enables long words to begin on one line and continue on this next, and tends to achieve a more even distribution of white space in justified text.
Words are broken and hyphenated according to standard grammar rules.
Automatic hyphenation is particularly effective when coupled with optimal paragraph layout (represented by the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.IsOptimalParagraphEnabled%2A> property).
`true` if automatic breaking and hyphenation of words is enabled; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether optimal paragraph layout is enabled or disabled.
Optimal paragraph layout is a feature that lays out paragraphs in the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> such that white space is distributed as evenly as possible.
Theoretically, this provides an optimized reading experience by eliminating distracting white space that can occur with line-justified text and other layout routines.
Optimal paragraph layout is particularly effective when coupled with automatic hyphenation (represented by the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.IsHyphenationEnabled%2A> property).
`true` if optimal paragraph layout is enabled; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets the height of each line of content.
Changing this value does not change the height of the associated text; rather, it changes the height of the line that contains the text.
To change the size of the text, use the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.FontSize%2A> property.
In addition to this property, the layout of lines in a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> is affected by its <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.LineStackingStrategy%2A> property.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than `0.0034` and equal to or less then `160000`.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, (excepting `Auto`) followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
Causes the line height to be determined automatically from the current font characteristics.
Equivalent to a property value of <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName>.
The height of each line, in device independent pixels, in the range 0.0034 to 160000.
A value of (equivalent to an attribute value of "Auto") causes the line height to be determined automatically from the current font characteristics.
<xref href="System.Windows.Controls.TextBlock.LineHeight"></xref> is set to a non-positive value.
Gets or sets the mechanism by which a line box is determined for each line of text within the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

One of the <xref href="System.Windows.LineStackingStrategy"></xref> values that specifies the mechanism by which a line box is determined for each line of text in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets an enumerator that can iterate the logical children of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
An enumerator for the logical children.
Gets or sets the maximum height for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageHeight%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageHeight%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageHeight%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
This property has no effect when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageHeight%2A> is set to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> (auto).
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The maximum height, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The default is <xref href="System.Double.PositiveInfinity"></xref> (no maximum page height).
Gets or sets the maximum width for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageWidth%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageWidth%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
This property has no effect when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> is set to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> (auto).
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The maximum width, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The default is <xref href="System.Double.PositiveInfinity"></xref> (no maximum page width).
Gets or sets the minimum height for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageHeight%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageHeight%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageHeight%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
This property has no effect when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageHeight%2A> is set to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> (auto).
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The minimum height, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets or sets the minimum width for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageWidth%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageWidth%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
This property has no effect when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> is set to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> (auto).
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
The minimum width, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

When overridden in a derived class, provides specific <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer"></xref> implementations to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/includes/tlasharptla-winclient-md.md)] infrastructure.
The implementation of this method is typically to call the constructor of a specific <xref:System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer> implementation, and return the result.
Called when one or more of the dependency properties that exist on the element have had their effective values changed.
Gets or sets the preferred height for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageHeight%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageHeight%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageHeight%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
Causes the page height to be determined automatically.
Equivalent to a property value of <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName>.
The preferred height, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
A value of (equivalent to an attribute value of "Auto") causes the page height to be determined automatically.
Gets or sets a value that indicates the thickness of padding space between the boundaries of a page and the page's content.

<xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PagePadding%2A> can be described as uniform in all directions (`PagePadding="10"`), or as four distinct values that represent left, top, right, and bottom padding independently (`PagePadding="5,0,10,20"`).

If a specified padding thickness exceeds the corresponding page dimension (for example, the sum of the left and right padding widths exceeds the page width), the thickness of the padding will be proportionally reduced to be no greater than the relevant page dimension.
String representation of a single <xref:System.Double> value to apply uniformly to all four thickness dimensions.
For example, a value of `"10"` is equivalent to a value of `"10,10,10,10"`.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
String representation of four ordered <xref:System.Double> values corresponding to independent thickness dimensions for left, top, right, and bottom, in this order.
The four values must be separated with commas; spaces are not allowed.

For example, "5,10,15,20" results in 5 pixels of padding to the left of content, 10 pixels of padding above content, 15 pixels of padding to the right of content, and 20 pixels of padding below the content.
A value described by *uniformThickness* followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`.
For example, `"1in"` provides uniform padding of 1 inch in all directions.
A value described by *independentThickness*, with each independent value followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`.
Unit specifiers may be mixed or omitted from one or more values.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Thickness"></xref> structure that specifies the amount of padding to apply, in device independent pixels.
The default is a uniform thickness of zero (0.0).
Gets or sets the preferred width for pages in a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

If viewed on a continuum, the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MinPageWidth%2A> property takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.MaxPageWidth%2A> property, which in turn takes precedence over the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.PageWidth%2A> property.
If all three properties are set on a given page, this is the order in which the properties are evaluated.
String representation of a <xref:System.Double> value equal to or greater than 0.0 but smaller than <xref:System.Double.PositiveInfinity?displayProperty=fullName>.
An unqualified value is measured in device independent pixels.
Strings need not explicitly include decimal points.
A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit specifiers: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`.
Causes the page width to be determined automatically.
Equivalent to a property value of <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName>.
The preferred width, in device independent pixels, for pages in the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
A value of (equivalent to an attribute value of "Auto") causes the page width to be determined automatically.
Sets the DPI for the FlowDocument, causing it to be remeasured and rerendered.
Should be used in Per Monitor DPI scenarios.
The DPI setting, from which a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Visual"></xref> or <xref href="System.Windows.UIElement"></xref> is rendered.
Gets or sets a value that indicates the horizontal alignment of text content.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.TextAlignment"></xref> values that specifies the desired alignment.
Gets or sets the effects to apply to the text of a <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.

A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.TextEffectCollection"></xref> containing one or more <xref href="System.Windows.Media.TextEffect"></xref> objects that define effects to apply to the text of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
Gets the currently effective typography variations for the text contents of the <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument.Typography%2A> property is applicable only to [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_opentype](~/includes/tlasharptla-opentype-md.md)] fonts.
A typography variant has no effect on fonts that do not support the variant.
For more information on this topic, see [Typography in WPF](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/typography-in-wpf.md).
A <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Typography"></xref> object that specifies the currently effective typography variations.
For a list of default typography values, see <xref href="System.Windows.Documents.Typography"></xref>.
Gets the service object of the specified type.
An object that specifies the type of service object to get.
`null` if there is no service object of type serviceType.
Defines the source object that performs actual content pagination.
The object that performs the actual content pagination.
Adds the text content of a node to the object.
The text to add to the object.
